body:
### Problem

rust-analyzer inlay hint enabled with `vim.lsp.inlay_hint.enable(true)
` by not showing at buffer open. But if toggle it with `:lua vim.lsp.inlay_hint.enable(true)` later, it will work.

I currently use `defer_fn` in `on_attach`to make it enabled by 2500ms in order to make the inlay hint show up on buffer open. (config is [here](https://github.com/levihuayuzhang/dotfiles/blob/161a5c4242bd70779c1effbabc5e6dafd3dec92e/nvim/.config/nvim/lua/plugins/lspconfig.lua#L14))

Wondering what is the best practice to use `vim.lsp.inlay_hint.enable()` or related staff to make rust-analyzer inlay hint showup on buffer open (without delay) after `nvim 0.10+`?

### Steps to reproduce using "nvim -u minimal_init.lua"

open a rust project with rust-analyzer enabled.

### Expected behavior

The inlay hint should showup with other info generated from rust-analyzer.

### Nvim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.11.0

### Language server name/version

rust-analyzer 0.3.2370-standalone (588948f267 2025-04-06)

### Operating system/version

Mac aarch64 Newest Stable

### Log file

_No response_

Server side issue report is [here](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-analyzer/issues/19548).

comment_data.body:
Yeah, [I have a similar hack in my config](https://github.com/MariaSolOs/dotfiles/blob/814421cb50330ed71122f7c08aa53a47be5774dc/.config/nvim/lua/lsp.lua#L94-L97)...

This does look like a server problem. https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-analyzer/issues/5349 reports the same problem happening in other editors, and it seems like it got "fixed" with https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-analyzer/commit/b1cb4ac13d5b625dd497692b6396287a30ff12e2, which adds a retry logic.

Yeah, maybe for now just use key shortcut to [toggle](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-analyzer/issues/5680#issuecomment-670935563) [it](https://github.com/MariaSolOs/dotfiles/blob/814421cb50330ed71122f7c08aa53a47be5774dc/.config/nvim/lua/lsp.lua#L7).

[rustaceanvim](https://github.com/mrcjkb/rustaceanvim) handled this by `toggle on and off` (so it can redraw the hints).

@levihuayuzhang are you suggesting that Nvim performs a toggle-on-and-off to "force" refresh on buffer open?

I tried to reproduce this bug with the minimal config, but I was unsuccessful. Is this issue still present in 0.11? Or does `vim.lsp.inlay_hint.enable` need to be conditionally executed, for example, with autocmd?

I think that 0.10 does have this issue, but I should have fixed it in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32446.

TL;DR, rust-analyzer sends a `workspace/inlayHint/refresh` request when it is "ready" to return valid results, and we previously did not handle this request correctly; this PR should fix it.

> @levihuayuzhang are you suggesting that Nvim performs a toggle-on-and-off to "force" refresh on buffer open?

Yes, I guess that's what link 1 does - which is a workaround. I didn't find other language server e.g. clangd have this kind of issue, inlay hints works fine with them at buffer open. RA have same issue on vscode and helix on my side for now. The nvim plugin 'rustaceanvim' just handled it properly. So it would be good if nvim could add this as workaround for now.

> RA have same issue on vscode and helix on my side for now.

Sounds like this is isolated to rust-analyzer? If this is not widespread to other LSes, we likely don't want to build in a workaround.

@justinmk We can easily expose such an API, as that is what the `workspace/inlayHint/refresh` handler does. IMHO, an API like that may be masking bugs, especially server bugs, so I think it's better not to. According to LSP, if necessary, the server can request a refresh through `workspace/inlayHint/refresh`.

I just confirmed that this bug could be consistently reproduced before https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32446, but the 0.11 version that includes this patch does not.

I am using the `0.11` version installed from homebrew(Mac aarch64). 
https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/issues/3701#issuecomment-2788374401 says this is related to the init time.
But the https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32446 should already fixed it.

Wondering the minimal config looks like (using `nvim-lspconfig` with `rust-analyzer`)?

> Wondering the minimal config looks like (using `nvim-lspconfig` with `rust-analyzer`)?

`h vim.lsp.config()`, `nvim-lspconfig` is unnecessary; it is merely a collection of pre-defined configurations after 0.11.

According to your description above, that vscode and helix have the same problem, I guess it should be rust-analyzer's bug.

However, if rust-analyzer heavily relies on `workspace/inlayHint/refresh` to correct previous invalid results, maybe nvim does have some vulnerability regarding it, but currently, there is insufficient evidence to suggest that this is the case.  I'm planning to refactor the handler for the request later, maybe that will be helpful.

Thanks for your information. It's really great that `nvim 0.11` ships with the lsp configuration APIs. (I just discovered it according to [this](https://lsp-zero.netlify.app/blog/lsp-config-overview.html) and the [doc](https://neovim.io/doc/user/lsp.html#lsp-config).ðŸŽ‰)

I did following "minimal manual config" for `nvim 0.11` in my `init.lua`:

```lua
vim.lsp.config['rust_analyzer'] = {
    cmd = { 'rust-analyzer' },
    filetypes = { 'rust' },
    root_markers = { 'Cargo.toml' },
}
vim.lsp.enable 'rust_analyzer'
```
But the problem seems still there. (Am I doing it right? Any suggestions?)

(btw, the plugin [rustaceanvim](https://github.com/mrcjkb/rustaceanvim) (version 6) seems not based on `nvim-lspconfig` anymore and it does require `nvim 0.11`. And it seems handle this problem well. I will looking it it to find how this plugin handle this issue.)

These should the fix for now if doing a config by using `nvim-lspconfig` for `nvim 0.11` (to make `inlay hints` for `rust-analyzer` at buffer open):
```lua
                   capabilities = {
                        experimental = {
                            serverStatusNotification = true,
                        },
                    },
                    handlers = {
                        ['experimental/serverStatus'] = function(
                            _,
                            result,
                            ctx
                        )
                            if
                                result.quiescent
                                and not _ran_once[ctx.client_id]
                            then
                                for _, bufnr in
                                    ipairs(
                                        vim.lsp.get_buffers_by_client_id(
                                            ctx.client_id
                                        )
                                    )
                                do
                                    if
                                        vim.lsp.inlay_hint.is_enabled {
                                            bufnr = bufnr,
                                        }
                                    then
                                        vim.lsp.inlay_hint.enable(
                                            false,
                                            { bufnr = bufnr }
                                        )
                                        vim.lsp.inlay_hint.enable(
                                            true,
                                            { bufnr = bufnr }
                                        )
                                    end
                                end
                                _ran_once[ctx.client_id] = true
                            end
                        end,
                    },
```
(sorry for the indents) (`_ran_once`should be a local variable declared before)

~~It seems this method may have some over head, which also discouraged by [rust-analyzer](https://rust-analyzer.github.io/book/contributing/lsp-extensions.html?highlight=serverstatus#server-status).~~ The `rust-analyzer` has [status notify](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/26511#issuecomment-1890954070), which can be relied on to do the redraw.

I think it's better to leave `inlay hints` diabled by default and manually triggered by shortcut when needed (vscode now provide shortcut for [peeking](https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_67#_toggle-inlay-hints) the inlay hints).

4. https://www.reddit.com/r/neovim/comments/1eyckqj/starting_with_inlay_hints_on_in_rust/
5. https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/26511#issuecomment-1884339225
6. https://neovim.io/doc/user/lsp.html#lsp-handler

> These should the fix for now if doing a config by using `nvim-lspconfig` for `nvim 0.11` (to make `inlay hints` for `rust-analyzer` at buffer open):
> ...

Another way to configure (rust-analyzer nvim-lspconfig), based on the [lsp_status](https://github.com/nvim-lualine/lualine.nvim/blob/master/lua/lualine/components/lsp_status.lua) component of [lualine](https://github.com/nvim-lualine/lualine.nvim/):
```lua
-- use auto_cmd to enable inlay hints at buffer open
                    on_attach = function(_, bufnr)
                        pcall(vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd, 'LspProgress', {
                            callback = function(event)
                                local kind = event.data.params.value.kind
                                local client_id = event.data.client_id
                                local work = lsp_work_by_client_id[client_id] or 0
                                local work_change = kind == 'begin' and 1
                                    or (kind == 'end' and -1 or 0)
                                lsp_work_by_client_id[client_id] = math.max(work + work_change, 0)

                                if
                                    vim.lsp.inlay_hint.is_enabled {
                                        bufnr = bufnr,
                                    }
                                    and lsp_work_by_client_id[client_id] == 0
                                then
                                    vim.lsp.inlay_hint.enable(false, { bufnr = bufnr })
                                    vim.lsp.inlay_hint.enable(true, { bufnr = bufnr })
                                    time = time + 1
                                    print(string.format('inlay hints redrew %d times', time))
                                end
                            end,
                        })
                    end,
```
It's using the `LspProgress` event to define when to redraw.
